head.title: Piazza Lives With Danger Of Catching

hedline.hl1: Piazza Lives With Danger Of Catching

abstract.p: Article discusses physical hazards associated with catching; New York Mets catcher Mike Piazza has been hit on forehead with backswing, collided with runners at home plate and missed playing time due to injuries (M)

block.p: Already this season, Mike Piazza has been knocked flat on his back by a 5-foot-10-inch utility player, thumped on the elbow by a helmet in a home plate collision and whacked on the forehead by a backswing.

There are all kinds of hazards about his job, said Piazza, who was back at catcher in the Mets lineup last night after missing Friday's game as he recovered from a concussion sustained on Wednesday, when the Dodgers' Gary Sheffield struck him on the head on his follow-through. If he has any fear, Piazza said, he might as well not play.

There are all kinds of hazards about his job, said Piazza, who was back at catcher in the Mets lineup last night after missing Friday's game as he recovered from a concussion sustained on Wednesday, when the Dodgers' Gary Sheffield struck him on the head on his follow-through. If he has any fear, Piazza said, he might as well not play.
''You're always going to have in the back of your mind that it's possible to have a serious injury,'' Piazza said.

Piazza knows that whenever he is injured -- he was unhurt in his collision with the Phillies' Kevin Sefcik, but missed four days with an elbow problem after a collision with the Rockies' Todd Helton -- he will be asked about the risks of his position. That frustrates him, he said, but he is a catcher, and there are few precautions he can take.

Piazza has no plans to squat farther behind the hitter to avoid an injury like Wednesday's. ''If I'm way back and I can't block a ball in the dirt,'' he said, ''the ball gets by and the runner scores, it's not doing any good.''

Further, there is nothing he can do to prevent home plate collisions. He worries about blowing out a knee, he said, but even smaller players like Sefcik are a threat today. ''You see some bone-jarring collisions,'' Piazza said. ''Twenty or thirty years ago, there was one guy on a team who could do that.''

The right-hander Rick Reed threw about 10 pitches off a mound last night as he tries to make his scheduled start on Tuesday. Reed missed Friday's scheduled start after sustaining a strained left oblique muscle last Saturday in St. Louis.

If he can't go on Tuesday and has to be placed on the disabled list, General Manager Steve Phillips said the Mets might recall a starter or reliever from Class AAA Norfolk. But while Bobby M. Jones, Grant Roberts and Dennis Springer will be considered, Paul Wilson will not. Wilson, the former No. 1 overall pick who is coming back from reconstructive elbow surgery in March 1999, is being skipped in the Norfolk rotation because of tenderness in his shoulder.
